title: Please don't move tags once released
body_html:
When you tag a version, please do not move it afterwards. For example, the v0.4.0 commit was initially on April 24 and the last commit (3749c58) is now a few days ago. This is a nightmare to follow when building wheels.

Instead, make a new release by updating the minor release number or stack commits and release them in another version. Users can then refer to a specific version when they have issues. This also make issues less difficult to reproduce.

I cannot stress enough how important this is for everyone following pytorch.

You can see a similar discussion on Tensorflow here : tensorflow/tensorflow#18424

Citing @boegel :

I know it can be very tempting to just quickly include another minor change and replacing the tag (probably assuming that nobody will notice), but it's really bad practice, especially for a popular project like TensorFlow (where you can be damned sure somebody will suffer from doing this).
Note that PyPI hard prevents you from doing this, if you would have pushed any pip packages there for the initial release, you would have been forced to do another point release (and rightfully so).

Tagging @soumith

Instead, make a new release by updating the minor release number or stack commits and release them in another version. Users can then refer to a specific version when they have issues. This also make issues less difficult to reproduce.
